column4: ok i've got a good one here. i have 2 NICs on the same hub with the same MAC address. both are receiving IP's and are able to ping, also do name resolution. however i can't access anything useful like HTTP, apt-get, even XCHAT. can anyone here atleast help figure out why?
yeah, they got the same MAC. change one of them

with MAC spoofing you will probably be able to get an ip, but won't be able to do anything useful. especially not on the same network (might work if the two MACs don't collide). 2 NIC with same MAC is asking for trouble.
it is common to spoof the MAC to fooling ISP's you're using only one computer when using a DSL modem connected to a router. But it only work 50% of the time.
oh yes, it works alright. but luck is involved. I've seen it work, i've seen it fail. I set it up myself for some ISP modems. but as I said, it is a hit'n'miss thing.
try to change one of them.
well, an easy solution: get a proper router
let the modem take the MAC address from the router and connect as many NICS as you need.

here's the thing. if you have a DSL modem you can either 1. let the modem handle the connection, ISP will get the MAC of NIC connected to modem. 2. let router handle the connection _through_ the modem, ISP will get whatever MAC you tell the router to use for the DSL connection. It's a done deal.
i'm not surprised. get a router. it's not more than 50?
it's because the hub isn't a router. a router translates traffic, a hub doesn't
the router can see which IP belong to which MAC and can redirect (or, hear this: "route") traffic.
a HUB is just a dummy connector. it got no intelligence
yes, but by chance only.
MAC spoofing is useful as long as only one computer is connected at one time.
nope, you did it correctly. but the first time it worked "reliably" was pure luck.
another possibility you have: modem connected to computer 1 (with two nics) connected to computer 2. computer 1 acts as a router. this is more stable.
router is the way to go. and they are cheap nowadays. If you spoof the MAC, only have one computer connected at a time and it will work fine.
your thoughts were in the right way at least. it's your HUB that make it fail since it can not direct traffic properly.
oh and one more thing, don't be tempted to get a switch instead of a router. a switch is only useful behind a router.
yep, been there myself :)
good choice. P.S. avoid D-Link
THAT I have thought of myself actually. extra cash
don't buy a second hand router. you might need the warranty! (trust me on that one)
